title: Boston firefighter who rescued three-year-old boy from a house fire in 1978 reunites with him 45 years later
text:
A Boston firefighter reunited with a now grown-up man that he rescued from a house fire 45 years ago Joe Gilmore rescued three-year-old Umar Fox and his sister Lisa from the burning building in 1978 The children's mother Silvia also attended the reunion to express her gratitude for saving their lives
A Boston firefighter enjoyed an emotional reunion with a man he saved from a house fire 45 years ago, when the latter was just a baby.
An emotional black and white image showed the incredible moment Joe Gilmore clutched two young children in his arms as he hauled them out of a burning building.
The firefighter, who was 33 at the time, was captured gritting his teeth as he heroically rescued the three-year-old boy and nine-year-old girl from the blaze that had begun in their three-story Dorchester house.
The children, siblings Lisa and Umar Fox, were visibly distressed and shocked in the image shot by George Rizer.
In a touching development, the three-year-old boy – who is now a 48-year-old man, met the hero that saved his life back in 1978 on Wednesday to express his gratitude.

Umar Fox and his mother Silvia Fox, 70, met Gilmore at Dorchester’s Florian Hall clutching a bunch of balloons bearing the message ‘thank you’.
‘Oh my god, you saved my kids,’ Mrs. Fox told Gilmore as she met him for the first time, the Boston Globe reported.
‘I’ve been waiting 45 years to say thank you,’ the grateful mother said as tears welled up in her eyes.
‘Little Umar isn’t so little anymore,’ Gilmore said as he approached Umar Fox – who was all smiles and laughter as he entered the hall.
Lisa Fox had been unable to attend the heartfelt reunion due to an illness.
Gilmore admitted that he had remembered the 1978 rescue, but didn’t think it was anything noteworthy because that was just the nature of his job.
But to Mrs. Fox – his act of service meant the world.
The single mother had been caring for other children at the day car center where she worked when the fire struck.
Her own children were home from school for a holiday break during the catastrophe.
Umar Fox is now a father of three and a stepdad to two others. He works as a school bus driver and transports over 65 kids and teenagers to school every day.
He had heard stories about the miraculous rescue throughout his life, but was desperate to find his lifesaver and thank him – and he was eventually able to track Gilmore down on social media.
During their touching meet-up – the trio playfully attempted to re-create the iconic photograph, with a now much larger Fox standing on a chair with his arms around Gilmore.
Fox joked that the picture captured his two favorite things – his harmonica, which he was clutching, and not wearing pants.

Fox opened up about his own lifesaving acts throughout his life – telling Gilmore that he saved a child from drowning when he was a teenager and managed to talk two people out of suicide while working as a recovery coach
‘Forty-five years after this incident, who would think we will all still be here to be able to talk about it?’ Gilmore said.
Fox opened up about his own lifesaving acts throughout his life – telling Gilmore that he saved a child from drowning when he was a teenager and managed to talk two people out of suicide while working as a recovery coach.
‘What you did, in turn, saved other people’s lives and brought more into the world,’ Fox said
‘You didn’t just do your job,’ Silvia Fox told Gilmore as they prepared to leave, ‘You did it well.’
The Fox family also invited the photographer Rizer to join in on their reunion.
Rizer had captured the incredible picture after he had been photographing a fire in Chinatown earlier that day.
He shot many fires and disasters over his career as a photographer – and explained that anytime he managed to capture a dramatic rescue it was down to ‘pure serendipity’.
‘The worst thing you can hear on the police scanner or fire scanner on the way to any event is, “children trapped,”‘ he said.
‘If I spent four minutes at that fire, it’d be a miracle,’ Rizer said, adding that he shot less than one roll of 35mm film during the disaster.
‘Joe did the heavy lifting — pun intended,’ Rizer said of Gilmore. ‘Media people, we just capture history, we don’t make it.’
